Award.AwardTitle: IBSS: Links Between Behavior and Attitudes Across Cultures

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will focus on identifying fundamental attributes of economic decision making, a set of measurements that the researchers call "econographics. The project also will focus on measuring econographics in countries throughout the world and within the U.S. over time, and as well as examining how these attributes relate to popular attitudes and participation in governmental processes. The researchers will conduct an incentivized survey that will measure econographics across thirteen countries, and over three times within the U.S. The countries selected to survey include many different types of governmental and economic environments, including parliamentary democracies with high redistribution, federal systems with a large informal economies, transitional democracies, developing democracies and authoritarian states. These states also have a variety of economic systems. Through their measurement of econographics across a broad spectrum of countries, the researchers will test hypotheses related to the processes through which these fundamental attributes correspond with the political environment and with economic performance. The three survey waves within the U.S. will straddle a national election to examine how major national events, which are known to change popular attitudes, affect econographics.

This project will provide new metrics to assess fundamentals of economic culture and decision making, and it will facilitate new modes of research to link behavioral economics with other social and behavioral science fields. The project will provide new insights related to the conduct of large-scale, cross-country, incentivized surveys, thereby facilitating future research based on empirical tests on representative samples of the population rather than on subjects in a social science laboratory. The project will provide valuable education and training opportunities for post-doctoral researchers and graduate students, and project results will provide valuable information and insights to assist policy makers and others in determining the most effective ways to attain socially desirable goals. This project is supported through the NSF Interdisciplinary Behavioral and Social Sciences Research (IBSS) competition.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project identified fundamental attributes of economic decision making, which we call econographics. To measure econographics, we surveyed representative samples of average Americans. The survey asked questions about economic choices, including taking risks, patience in waiting for future rewards, and sacrificing to help or harm other people. We also asked questions about confidence in judgments, cognitive skill, politicalattitudes and activity, and have personal characteristics such as age, gender, and socio-economic status. The intellectual merit in our work was to ask a wider range of questions than ever before in a sample precisely designed to represent all Americans. 

Our main finding is that answers to 21 questions can be distilled into six basic econographic traits. The six traits are associated with sociality (generosity, and a dislike of inequality), risk (aversion to risk, and to uncertainty), patience (impulsivity), and overconfidence. The statistical procedure deliberately finds traits that are separate from each other (e.g., more generous people are not more or less impulsive than other people). 

Another intellectually meritorious finding is that people with lower cognitive skill are more tolerant of financial losses. They do not exhibit the same “loss aversion”, which was previously thought to be a basic feature of human nature. This finding was a big surprise to us and to other experts. We discovered it because our representative sample included a wide range of cognitive skills (rather than just sampling the usual college students).   

There is also ongoing analysis of how econographics and political attitudes are linked, and new data from several foreign countries which have not yet been analyzed.

We also used created new procedures that can improve a lot of social science.  We used an OR-IV method to reduce the noisy “measurement error” in responses. When correlating traits with personal differences, error tends to shrink genuine effects so that they look smaller than they really are. Our method is the equivalent of using a “better microscope” to see effects more clearly. Using this method, we were able to find stronger correlations between demographics, SES and econographics than others have found. We also implemented methods to personalize questions. Our adaptive method does not waste time asking people questions, when we can already be statistically confident about what their answers would be.   

The methods used in this project can improve future surveys with many of the same features. The data produced by this project will also be freely available to scholars who want to run different analyses. 

The broader impact of these findings is that they can help guide policy recommendations. Helping people to make better decisions on their own behalf requires a basic understanding of their risk-taking, patience, sociality, etc. Consider charitable giving as an example. In our survey, generosity toward strangers and a desire to have equal outcomes are different traits. That suggests the people who will spend time, money and energy to reduce social inequality are different than the people who will help strangers because they are simply generous.  

Another broader impact can come from our discovery that people with less cognitive skill tolerate financial losses. Poverty is associated with both having more frequent financial losses—which contributes to poverty-- and being especially vulnerable to losses. Our findings suggests a novel role for cognitive skill in this process.
